docs.lead_paragraph: Some have more of one; some, of the other. The best have a bit of both. This spring, no matter what city they were created in, the clothes that look and feel the newest blend the by-now classic ease of men's-wear and sportswear separates with a shapely curviness that hugs the body, emphasizing the breasts, waist and hips - especially the hips. Such clothes bring together two currently strong yet disparate design directions that are interpreted in many different and individual ways in the collections of trend-setting designers in New York, Paris, London and Milan. The combination calls on designers' cleverest devices as well as on an interesting alchemy of fabric and form. The resultant fashions possess a sort of chic that seems tailor-made for the 1986 woman. They are feminine yet comfortable - easy to move around in at a fast pace.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reverence for the fine arts, the applied arts and just plain style is basic to being French, and cultural curiosity is as inbred as the taste for lamb on Sunday or a tolerance for halfhearted heating and Lilliputian-sized elevators. In Paris, people who make things happen have a way of dreaming up new ideas while reanimating old ones. Artists in all fields seem to respect computer technology as much as Moliere, Rameau or Watteau. The Concorde jet and the new superfast TGV train are mobile monuments to a particularly French kind of inventiveness - they are what happen when realism meets up with fantasy. French fashion designers are singularly adept at exploiting this dichotomy.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: My attention has been drawn to Steven Marcus's review of my recent biography, ''Lord Alfred Douglas'' (Nov. 17). Mr. Marcus may be an authority on English sexuality and pornography in Victorian times, but he appears remarkably ignorant of English poetry. Otherwise he would not have written that apart from his association with Oscar Wilde, Douglas's life ''had no meaning at all'' and he was ''an absolute nullity.''

docs.snippet: THE GOD OF MIRRORS By Robert Reilly. 403 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. MAKING novels out of the lives of historical figures is always dangerous. This is particularly so for Oscar Wilde. Even 40 years ago, Richard Aldington could ...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE GOD OF MIRRORS By Robert Reilly. 403 pp. Boston: The Atlantic Monthly Press. $17.95. MAKING novels out of the lives of historical figures is always dangerous. This is particularly so for Oscar Wilde. Even 40 years ago, Richard Aldington could write, ''Almost everything that could be said about Oscar Wilde has been said already.'' Not quite. Definitive biographies and fictionalizations kept emerging, and Wilde himself spoke beyond the grave, for ''De Profundis'' was published uncut for the first time in 1960. The dangers in Wilde's case are further compounded by the fact that he self-consciously turned his own life into a fiction. One of his most persistent paradoxes, which he managed to make entirely convincing, was that life imitates art. His acquaintances all testified that Wilde's greatest art was his conversation. His disregard of facts was one of the primary facts about him.

docs.lead_paragraph: IN making documentary films, according to Joyce Chopra, who has until now specialized in them, ''You are excited by what you already see, and you accept it as a given.'' In fiction film making, ''you make up an entire world.'' Miss Chopra did the latter in directing ''Smooth Talk'' (review on page C17), her first fiction feature, about the coming-of-age of a 15-year-old girl named Connie (Laura Dern) at the hands of a mysterious and possibly dangerous stranger (Treat Williams). Her biggest worry in making the transition to fiction was not having to work with actors, but the matter of staging. ''With a documentary, you go to the situation and cover the scene, you don't have to decide where to move,'' she said. ''But this time, I had to ask myself, 'How do you break a scene down? Where do you put the camera, and why?' '' The two Joyces involved in ''Smooth Talk,'' Miss Chopra and the writer Joyce Carol Oates (from whose story ''Where Are You Going, Where Have You Been?'' the film is adapted), have never met. ''She really did not want to be a part of it, and it actually relieved me, too,'' Miss Chopra said, although the author has since conveyed her liking for the film.

docs.lead_paragraph: TWO of Cole Porter's most beguiling standards, ''Begin the Beguine,'' and ''Just One of Those Things,'' can be savored in their original dramatic contexts Sunday and Monday when the New Amsterdam Theater Company presents a concert revival of ''Jubilee.'' A distinguished cast will perform the complete score and most of the libretto of the 1935 musical romp, which has a book by Moss Hart in addition to Porter's music and lyrics. The cast, which includes Carole Shelley, who won a Tony for ''The Elephant Man,'' Alyson Reed, Paula Laurence, Rebecca Luker, Reed Jones, John Remme and Robert Cook, will be joined by a full orchestra and chorus. The production opens the fifth season of a musical theater troupe whose glowing, meticulous concert revivals of vintage Broadway shows have drawn a growing, and enthusiastic following. Since the company's 1981 debut in the Sigmund Romberg-Oscar Hammerstein 2d hit-filled 1928 score of ''The New Moon,'' it has presented concert productions of such Broadway classics as ''Eileen,'' ''The Firefly,'' ''Rosalie,'' ''One Touch of Venus,'' ''Sweethearts,'' ''Roberta,'' ''Leave It to Jane,'' ''Music in the Air,'' ''Sweet Adeline'' as well as a tribute to ''George White's Scandals.''

docs.lead_paragraph: HASKELL WEXLER, the Oscar-winning cameraman (''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' and ''Bound for Glory''), is angered and grieved by United States support of guerrilla forces attempting to overthrow Nicaragua's Sandanista Government. However, ''Latino,'' Mr. Wexler's second film as writer-director (his first, ''Medium Cool,'' was released in 1969), doesn't do justice to his passion. It doesn't even do justice to the fury expressed in ''Target Nicaragua: Inside a Secret War,'' the 1983 documentary Mr. Wexler made with Saul Landau on the same subject.
